comments.commentBody: So what is that definition of 'insanity'? Will the US never learn!

I'm currently a student at a university. Over the course of my first two years I took a few online courses and found them a complete waste of time. Online courses are a great way to get a degree without actually learning anything at all. Without exception they were dummed down to a sixth or seventh grade level.
The biggest reason for offering online courses is for the revenue they generate.
Not everyone needs or wants an education so why diminish the value of higher education by making it something everyone can achieve?

Harrison Bergeron anybody?

I'm proud of the hard work and sacrifice that was needed to get where I am and I'm not threatened by those who are still better than I by a wide margin. I'm also fifty now, with thirty years spent in the trades with only a high school education where I did quite well.

So one further thought is that we are snubbing those who do so much for themselves, their families and society without a degree.

Just as I predicted, a comment about the cost.
How really petty, when just a few short years ago we spent $1 trillion and several thousand lives to go to a war, that was unjustified, and wrong from the start.

How much will come out of your pay to help these kids? Will it even come close to what we are now paying for the Great G.W. Bush Crusade?
When we have a few more female judges, maybe we can see.

Einstein did not believe in a personal god. In reply to a question as to whether he believed in any sort of a god, he said, "Your question [about God] is the most difficult in the world. It is not a question I can answer simply with yes or no. I am not an Atheist. I do not know if I can define myself as a Pantheist. The problem involved is too vast for our limited minds." (Find this in the Wiki article on "Religious views of Albert Einstein."

I may as well add that his close friend Kurt Gödel, also at the Institute for Advanced Study, "considered with Aristotle and Gottlob Frege to be one of the most significant logicians in history," did believe in a personal god. See his Wiki biography; and you might also research his version of the ontological proof of the existence of God. (You will need background in sentential logic, quantification theory and modal logic.)
Hey Kagni, I wondered the same thing.

How do you know there are no repercussions? Maybe a scientist could unravel the difference between who you are now and who you might have been had you not sought out exposure to so much terrible mind-numbing violence. Maybe you're so desensitized to violence now that you can't even feel the repercussions inside your own self. That is a real possibility that is being raised here by the science. Scientists can measure things about us that we often don't realize about ourselves.

This article is poorly written and filled with anecdotal evidence. Millions of children (including myself) have played hyper violent video games for years with no repercussions - let alone violent tendencies. The issue seems to be gun control and mental health awareness and assistance.
I have two masters degrees from MIT, and MIT is one of the few things in my 78 years that lived up tp it's hype.
Really?  So if daddy has his name on a building at Princeton, his children or other connected family members are automatically part of the elite 1% of academic achievers?   Give me a break!

Of course it doesnt matter that ASU is consistently ranked as one of the top 10 party schools in the nation. On the one hand, ASU is pursuing a great model of education for the masses. On the other hand, the elite schools care about only attracting elite and motivated and capable students. Princeton has the lowest average graduating debt in the country. This is because (in addition to rich students) it can attract students who will be monetarily successful and has a proven track record of producing monetarily successful students.

Overall, the top 1% of schools are academically excellent, and justifiably have low admit rates. This includes Princeton, Harvard, Yale, Duke, Columbia, etc. At the other end of the spectrum are the less elite schools who offer students who may not be in the top 1% of academics an excellent education. And this is where ASU excels. The issue is not the US World News & Report values acceptance rate. It's that acceptance rate should only matter for the 1% of capable students. 99% of universities/colleges should be more like ASU. 1% of universities/colleges should be more like the Ivies and their like (Stanford, MIT, Cal Tech, Cal Berkley etc.)

If we hadn't bought into the crazy neocon lies about Iran's non-existent nuclear weapons program and the non-existent threat to Israel, the world would be a much more stable place. Iran is the major regional power here. Trying to deny this or to cripple the Iranians has led to the crazy scenario we now have.

Americans now see involving Iran to achieve stability in the region as a contradictory policy only because the right wing has so thoroughly demonized Iran. Iran has many negatives but not having diplomatic relations with Tehran for 40 years (!) has brought us to this point. Now we need the Iranians and our ridiculous policy vis-a-vis Iran has given them the upper hand. Let us hope they are more charitable than we have been.

I think they just become more sensitive to issues they had not considered in a certain light before.  Justice Renquist's daughter was not affected by the case he decided regarding suing a state employer.  It is unlikely to ever affect her directly.  But he viewed the case more "liberally," perhaps because of his personal experience of seeing how hard it can be to be a divorced, working mother and probably how she stepped up to her responsibilities.

Way overdue. Iran should have been recognized in 2001, and the whole sanction regime junked. In comparison to our ally Saudi Arabia, Iran is an angel. In 1979 they took hostages of the American embassy. In 2001, 14 Saudis were involved in attacking the Pentagon and the WTC, and the entire thing was financed by Saudi money - which also financed the Sunni insurgency in Iraq, and has financed ISIS.
There is no reason not to ally with Iran, here. The threat to Israel is bogus - I mean, Israel armed Iran against Saddam H. in the 1980s. Get real. The only way the US can keep a balance in the Middle East is if it stops trying to crush the main Shi'ite power and returns to the balancing act between the Saudis and the Iranians.

Pretty much all of business management theory and practice is based upon Peter Drucker's work dating back to the 1940s, who was a Schumpeterian, heavily influenced by his early theory of economic development, that growth isn't through minor fluctuations in commodity trading, but rather through the market changes caused by innovation.

Contra Clayton Christiansen, creative destruction / innovation is not just the disruptive kind, it's often incremental. Sources of innovation can be everything from noticing an incongruity in what "everyone believes", or the "unexpected", or exploiting minor changes in perception, meaning and mood.

The Germans by that measure are great innovators - look at the little things Mercedes Benz continually does to improve their automobiles. Look at the Airbus A380, which is assembled in Hamburg.

So, I care not whether Christiansen's specific theory is valid or not. What surprises me is that you're conflating his specific theories with the broader belief in innovation promoted by "Silicon Valley types", and that we should keep doing what we do well. The vast majority of SV companies are refinements on existing ideas - they're not disruptive at all. Even for the ones that are potentially disruptive, how am I supposed to read this: we should still keep driving gasoline cars, and Elon Musk is wrong to pursue Tesla? We should just keep investing in Space Shuttles until the end of the century, and he's also wrong to pursue SpaceX?
Sometimes the wisdom I must exercise is to do nothing.

Tell Iran to bail out corrupt Maliki, if they want to keep their Islamic client state intact. We need to stay out of this tribal blood feud. No matter who wins, they will be Sharia compliant and Islamic to the core. If the Iraqis want a Shia theocracy allied with Iran...let them fight for it, but why should we? It's clear the Sunni insurgents (ISIS), even if they manage to take over the country, have nothing to offer anyone but murder, death, terror, slavery and oppression. These fanatics want to turn the clock back 1400 years, and they just might succeed. The people of Iraq had a chance to have a modern country and democracy, but they blew it, because they refused to cooperate with us. If they had helped us instead of fighting tooth and nail with us and each other, we would have rebuilt their entire country from the ground up and paid for the privilege. Look at them now.

I believe that your analysis comports with that of the current administration.

However, I believe the Obama administration is currently struggling with the horrifically brutal mechanics of a war it never wanted and would never have started.

How, exactly, do we annihilate ISIS without causing the deaths of innocent civilians? Likewise, how do we protect the many that will die if ISIS is allowed to gain territory in the region?

The Sunni/Shi'ite division has existed from the first century AD. The divisions are now emboldened by arms and money from proxy states, with economic interests in mind. Let's just destroy every munitions factory on the planet, including gun manufacturers, and lets get on with life.

Keep Baghdad from coming under the thrall of Tehran?

Maliki, long before he was placed ("elected") to lead the "democratic" government of Iraq, was a creature of Iran.

He has been such a creature ever since. But for that matter, who else should the Shiites of Iraq identify with other then the Shiites of Iran? Let's not forget, when the shoe was on the other foot, and that foot was Saddam Hussein's, wearing a boot on the neck of the Iraqi Shia, the Iraqi Sunni, Baathist or otherwise, did not give Iraqi Shia reason to identify with them.

Do we in the US either expect or accept to be criticized for identifying and allying with the other predominantly Christian countries of the West, or elsewhere? Why should the peoples of Iraq and Iran as well be given the same courtesies we so take for granted for ourselves.

We believe in self-determination - right up to the moment that others self-determine that they don't wish to side with us. And yet we claim to champion democracy, and want to spread democracy. Bull. We want to spread obeisance to our imagined magnificence - and our corporate agenda. But "they hate us for our freedom."

I question what appears to be the premise underlying Mr. Simon’s assessment that "Washington’s support for the Maliki government will put further strain on its ties to the gulf states,” and prevent “an optimal outcome for Washington.”

Gulf state leaders are skilled practitioners of the three-dimensional chess game of diplomacy played in their region of the world, which is always based on self-interest. They may bluster publicly, but so what? They can’t credibly fault the US for acting in its self-interest by moving against ISIS in some way.

Also, must we base our short-term responses on the premise that we might be able to keep Baghdad from coming under the thrall of Tehran? I don't see evidence in this pages recently that suggests we can.

Helping the Iraqis avoid ISIS domination is a good thing to do, even if the effort falls short. We should stop measuring our policies against academic notions of ideal outcomes. In this part of the world, there are none.

We are not really forging an “alliance” with the Maliki government, but merely using it as a chess piece. Smart moves will help regional Shi’ite forces crush the Sunni invasion of Iraq.

I think Mr. Simon’s premise that somewhere in this madness lies an optimal outcome runs counter to reality. Time will tell, of course. But for now, if Tehran is the only likely “winner” here, so be it.

Tehran’s potential gains are relatively small compared to the West’s stake in seeing the ISIS movement annihilated.

The concern I have about "the world (including Germany) would be a poorer place, because there would be less innovation" is that there are many many products that we use and take for granted every day that were not invented in the US.  While the US may be excellent at innovation, it's also smart enough to know a good thing when it sees it, and adopts it as its own.

It is sweet of you to think women superior but that is a bit of a burden.  We're all in this together and we need to honor and respect everyone.  I, too have 3 daughters. And 4 granddaughters, two sisters and seven female first cousins.  I think men are pretty neat (and in our family they can seem scarce too).

I'm sure Jerry Lee is using his best English and it's not difficult to understand. He says let those who have a current interest in Iraq be those to step in and render assistance/protect their.interests. For example, China has significant investments in oil wells and receives half of Iraqi oil exports. I know American and European oil companies are in Iraq but didn't check where that oil production goes. Jerry Lee says the US has no ongoing interest (fold 'em meaning cut the losses) but I disagree there are no ongoing national interests for our country, both economic and geopolitical. He says Iraq should pay a high price for our renewed military involvement without saying what that would be. Then there's a possible non-sequitur about resolution involving what's desired by the populace versus, by implication, a non-representative government. Perhaps he's towing the Obama line of military aid conditioned by political establishment inclusiveness, ethnic Kurds and Sunni Arabs, that the Iraqi leadership (including Iran) have been resisting and even sabotaging.
Brilliant turn, Mr. Obama.  Dangerous, but brilliant.

Easing sanctions on Iran and moving towards normalization of relations with the Ayatollahi Islamic Republic is one thing; becoming a partner of Iran against the Sunni insurgents to protect Maliki's Shiite regime in Iraq is another. The first is OK; the second will be a blunder with grave consequences.

During the first stages of the Syrian crisis refusing to include Iran in the international peace-making process was a blunder. In our discussion concerning the ongoing Iraqi crisis, are we repeating the same mistake by 'forgetting' that a country called Saudi Arabia DOES EXIST?

Direct and open Iranian military intervention in Iraq will inevitably force not only Saudi Arabia but almost all Arab countries to respond in kind. A US-Iran partnership in Iraq now will mean that we will be fighting along with Iranians against our Arab allies of more than half a century!

a century! century! ces

Jonsey.  By you comment I assume you are addressing me.  While your tone is a little condescending, I will give you my thoughts and you can make of them what you will.  If you were to dig a little deeper than just googling 1953 you might learn that Khomeini and his followers were just as much or more the enemies of Mossadegh's political successors as they were of the Shah, and in taking power, they defeated both camps.  The notion that the 1979 revolution was a redress of the wrongs of 1953 and that somehow the US is thus forever at fault for everything bad in Iran,  is a simplistic "Blame America First" talking point.  While one never knows with contra-factual history, it is quite likely the Islamic Revolution would have come about even if Mossadegh was never overthrown.
implied commitments - how interesting - bush actually signed a commitment for US forces to be out of iraq in 2011?

This is probably a very unpopular idea, but it occurs to me that if the whole of the Shiite dominated zone in southern were to become part of Iran, there would simply be more Iranians.  They would actually be easier to deal with, from a foreign policy point of view than they are now, and Iran could defend them.

Obama should appoint Les Gelb as his foreign policy adviser. Charlie Rose's first segment with Gelb and Robin Wright is well worth watching. Among other things, they discussed how the Gulf States are funding the ISIS, hiding behind their 'businessmen'.

I listen to college courses on CD in my car all the time.

They are great and the company finds the best professors in the US who are passionate and eloquent.

I have 8 years of college and post graduate education. I did not have a single professor who mentored me or who was engaged. I did have a bunch of tired old people who were to busy or too removed from the real world to see me or to offer meaningful advice.

Until you figure out another way to get a job, I'll take the credentials for employment and leave the reading of endless irrelevant classics to you.
